title: A day in the life of a Mongolian queen - Anne F. Broadbridge

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the khatun of the Golden Horde in the Mongolian Empire?

options.text: Queen Boraqchin

options.label: B
options.text: Batu Khan

options.label: C
options.text: Genghis Khan

options.label: D
options.text: Boraqchin's husband

options.label: B
options.text: To ensure constant water and lush grass in summer

options.label: C
options.text: To move to a new location for trade

options.label: D
options.text: To attend to royal duties

options.text: Twenty

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Forty

title: The truth about electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) - Helen M. Farrell

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between the early years of electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) and modern ECT?

options.label: A
options.text: The dosage of electrical current used

options.label: B
options.text: The duration of the treatment session

options.label: C
options.text: The method of administering the treatment

options.label: D
options.text: The physical indication of the treatment

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary goal of ECT in treating patients with severe depression or bipolar disorder?

options.label: A
options.text: To induce a long-term coma

options.label: B
options.text: To stimulate the release of certain neurotransmitters

options.label: C
options.text: To reduce symptoms of depression

options.label: D
options.text: To increase the production of hormones

multiple-choice.question: What is a common side effect of ECT that may improve over time?

options.label: A
options.text: Memory loss for up to a year

options.label: B
options.text: Fatigue and nausea

options.label: C
options.text: Difficulty concentrating

options.label: D
options.text: Memory loss for up to weeks and months

multiple-choice.question: What is the recommended frequency of ECT sessions for patients with severe depression or bipolar disorder?

options.label: A
options.text: One session per week for several months

options.label: B
options.text: Two or three sessions per week for several weeks

options.label: C
options.text: One session per month for a year

options.label: D
options.text: No set frequency, as it varies from patient to patient

multiple-choice.question: What is the most likely outcome for patients who undergo ECT treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: No improvement in symptoms

options.label: B
options.text: Improvement in symptoms after just one session

options.label: C
options.text: Improvement in symptoms after several sessions

options.label: D
options.text: Permanent memory loss

title: What happens in your brain when you pay attention? - Mehdi Ordikhani-Seyedlar

multiple-choice.question: What are two ways you direct your attention?

options.label: A
options.text: Overt and covert attention, and also mental and physical attention.

options.label: B
options.text: Overt and covert attention, and also internal and external attention.

options.label: C
options.text: Overt and covert attention, and also voluntary and involuntary attention.

options.label: D
options.text: Overt and covert attention, and also conscious and subconscious attention.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of using cognitive brain-machine interfaces?

options.label: A
options.text: To build models for computers to recognize how well our brain functions.

options.label: B
options.text: To create assistive devices for therapies.

options.label: C
options.text: To train our brain to inhibit distractors.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

options.label: A
options.text: It processes visual information.

options.label: B
options.text: It filters information coming in from the right flicker.

options.label: C
options.text: It inhibits information coming from the ignored flicker.

options.label: D
options.text: It is responsible for higher cognitive functions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential application of cognitive brain-machine interfaces?

options.label: A
options.text: To help people with ADHD focus for a long time on a single task.

options.label: B
options.text: To enable people to communicate through a computer.

options.label: C
options.text: To help people understand the thoughts of a person in a coma.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of finding brainwave patterns when people think about images or letters?

options.label: A
options.text: It can help us understand the thoughts of a person in a coma.

options.label: B
options.text: It can enable a computer to communicate for people who can't speak.

options.label: C
options.text: It can help us build models for computers to recognize how well our brain functions.

options.label: D
options.text: It can help us create assistive devices for therapies.

options.label: D

options.label: C

title: How Thor got his hammer - Scott A. Mellor

options.text: He wanted to punish the dwarves for their past mistakes.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: He got stung by a black fly on his hand, but continued working.

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: Brokk and Eitri won and created the finest treasures.

options.label: C
options.text: The competition ended in a tie, and both families created equally fine treasures.

options.label: D
options.text: The competition was cancelled due to Loki's interference.

multiple-choice.question: How did Brokk finally get revenge on Loki for tricking him?

options.label: B
options.text: He sewed Loki's mouth shut with an awl.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: He turned Loki into a golden arm ring.

title: Why you should put down your cell phone and be here now - Renny Gleeson

multiple-choice.question: What is the problem with the rise of a culture of availability driven by mobile device proliferation?

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: Paradoxica

options.label: B
options.text: Trollaria

options.label: C
options.text: Logica

options.label: D
options.text: Realm of Reason

multiple-choice.question: What is the troll's condition for releasing the creatures it has caught?

options.label: A
options.text: If the narrator says something false, the troll will release the creatures.

options.label: B
options.text: If the narrator says something true, the troll will release the creatures.

options.label: C
options.text: If the narrator says something paradoxical, the troll will release the creatures.

options.label: D
options.text: If the narrator says something that is not a sentence, the troll will release the creatures.

options.label: B
options.text: Lewis Carroll

options.label: C
options.text: Bertrand Russell

options.label: D
options.text: Alfred North Whitehead

options.label: B
options.text: Saying something that is true and depends on what the troll wants to do.

options.label: C
options.text: Saying something that is false and depends on what the troll wants to do.

options.label: D
options.text: Saying something that is a riddle.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The troll will release all its prisoners, including the creatures and the brother.

options.label: D
options.text: The troll will eat the brother and the creatures.

title: Can animals be deceptive? - Eldridge Adams

multiple-choice.question: What are the three defining hallmarks of deception by non-human animals?

options.label: A
options.text: Misleading the receiver, benefiting the deceiver, and accidental behavior

options.label: B
options.text: Misleading the receiver, benefiting the deceiver, and adapting to environment

options.label: C
options.text: Misleading the receiver, benefiting the deceiver, and being an accident

options.label: D
options.text: Misleading the receiver, benefiting the deceiver, and being a threat

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of animal mimicry in nature?

options.label: A
options.text: A leaf-tailed gecko changing its color to match its surroundings

options.label: B
options.text: A harmless scarlet kingsnake evolving red, yellow, and black patterns resembling those of the venomous eastern coral snake

options.label: C
options.text: An orchid looking and smelling like a female wasp to attract male wasps

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of animal deception where an animal anticipates the reactions of other animals and adjusts its behavior accordingly?

options.label: A
options.text: The octopus changing its colors to match its surroundings

options.label: B
options.text: The dwarf chameleon color-matching its environment more closely when it sees a bird predator

options.label: C
options.text: The fork-tailed drongo sounding a false alarm when other species have captured prey

options.label: D
options.text: The mantis shrimp molting as it grows

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of animal deception where an animal uses a signal to trick members of its own species?

options.label: A
options.text: The mantis shrimp molting as it grows

options.label: B
options.text: The mantis shrimp bluffing against rivals by spreading its large limbs

options.label: C
options.text: The fork-tailed drongo sounding a false alarm when other species have captured prey

options.label: D
options.text: The leaf-tailed gecko changing its color to match its surroundings

multiple-choice.question: Can animals deceive with intent, or is it simply a reflexive behavior?

options.label: A
options.text: Animals can deceive with intent, and it's a complex behavior

options.label: B
options.text: Animals can deceive with intent, but it's a simple behavior

options.label: C
options.text: Animals can't deceive with intent, and it's a reflexive behavior

options.label: D
options.text: We'll never be able to answer whether animals deceive with intent or not

options.label: C
options.text: A symbol of the Second Coming

options.label: D

title: The dangerous race for the South Pole - Elizabeth Leane

multiple-choice.question: Who had spent nearly two years preparing his Arctic expedition and was about to embark on a journey to the South Pole?

options.label: A
options.text: Robert F. Scott

options.label: B
options.text: Roald Amundsen

options.label: C
options.text: Robert Peary

options.label: D
options.text: Frederick Cook

multiple-choice.question: What was the main difference between Roald Amundsen's and Robert F. Scott's expeditions to the South Pole?

options.label: A
options.text: Amundsen had more men in his team, while Scott had more dogs.

options.label: B
options.text: Amundsen's team was smaller and more focused on reaching the pole, while Scott's team was larger and more focused on scientific research.

options.label: C
options.text: Amundsen's team was led by a British naval officer, while Scott's team was led by a Norwegian explorer.

options.label: D
options.text: Amundsen's team was better equipped with motorized sledges, while Scott's team relied on ponies.

multiple-choice.question: Why did Roald Amundsen decide to alter the course of his expedition from the North Pole to the South Pole?

options.label: A
options.text: Because he had heard that the North Pole was already claimed by American explorers.

options.label: B
options.text: Because he wanted to compete with Robert F. Scott in a 'race to the Pole'.

options.label: C
options.text: Because he had a change of heart and wanted to explore the South Pole instead.

options.label: D
options.text: Because he had received news that the American explorers Frederick Cook and Robert Peary had staked rival claims to the achievement.

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of Robert F. Scott's expedition to the South Pole?

options.label: A
options.text: They reached the pole first and returned safely.

options.label: B
options.text: They reached the pole second and returned safely.

options.label: C
options.text: They reached the pole, but two of the five men succumbed to frostbite, starvation, and exhaustion.

options.label: D
options.text: They did not reach the pole and returned safely.

multiple-choice.question: Why did Robert F. Scott's team not receive the prearranged rendezvous with a team sent from their base?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of a series of mishaps, misjudgements, and miscommunications.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the team sent from the base was delayed due to bad weather.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the team sent from the base was unable to find Scott's team in the vast Antarctic terrain.

options.label: D
options.text: Because Scott's team had decided to abandon their expedition and return home.

title: Why you should talk to strangers - Kio Stark

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why people often have a bias when it comes to interacting with strangers?

options.label: A
options.text: They expect strangers to be hostile or aggressive.

options.label: B
options.text: They expect strangers to be dishonest or untrustworthy.

options.label: C
options.text: They rely on categories instead of using their senses.

options.label: D
options.text: They are afraid of being judged or evaluated.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the benefit of using our senses instead of our fears when interacting with strangers?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows us to be more aggressive and confrontational.

options.label: B
options.text: It liberates us from our fears and biases.

options.label: C
options.text: It allows us to be more suspicious and judgmental.

options.label: D
options.text: It allows us to be more isolated and disconnected.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the brief, emotional connections that can be made with strangers?

options.label: A
options.text: Fleeting intimacy

options.label: B
options.text: Deep connection

options.label: C
options.text: Meaningful interaction

options.label: D
options.text: Superficial conversation

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is one of the unwritten rules of interacting with strangers in many parts of the US?

options.label: A
options.text: To ignore strangers and avoid eye contact.

title: Can you solve the time travel riddle? - Dan Finkel

multiple-choice.question: What is the minimum number of chrono-nodules needed to be certain that a red or blue triangle will be created, allowing the speaker to return to the present?
What is the name of the branch of mathematics that developed from the problem of finding the minimum number of chrono-nodules needed to create a red or blue triangle?

options.label: A
options.text: Graph Theory

options.label: B
options.text: Ramsey Theory

options.label: C
options.text: Combinatorics

options.label: D
options.text: Topology

multiple-choice.question: What is the key insight that allows the speaker to prove that six nodules will always create a red or blue triangle?

options.label: A
options.text: The speaker realizes that six is an even number, so it must be sufficient.

options.label: B
options.text: The speaker considers the possible ways that the sixth nodule can connect to the other five nodules.

options.label: C
options.text: The speaker uses a complex mathematical formula to calculate the minimum number of nodules needed.

options.label: D
options.text: The speaker simply guesses that six is the correct answer.

multiple-choice.question: What is the consequence of having fewer than six nodules?

options.label: A
options.text: The speaker will be transported to a different time period.

options.label: B
options.text: The speaker will be stuck in the past forever.

options.label: C
options.text: The speaker will experience a temporal instability that raises the chances of the portal collapsing.

options.label: D
options.text: The speaker will be able to return to the present without any problems.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main challenge that the speaker faces in trying to find the minimum number of nodules needed to create a red or blue triangle?

options.label: A
options.text: The speaker must navigate a complex network of connections between the nodules.

options.label: B
options.text: The speaker must consider the possible ways that the nodules can connect to each other.

options.label: C
options.text: The speaker must use a complex mathematical formula to calculate the minimum number of nodules needed.

options.label: D
options.text: The speaker must simply guess the correct answer.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The struggle for control and authority

options.label: D

options.label: D

options.text: A Karass is a group of people who appoint significance to meaningless associations, while a Granfalloon is a group of people who are cosmically linked around a shared purpose

options.label: B
options.text: A Karass is a group of people who are cosmically linked around a shared purpose, while a Granfalloon is a group of people who appoint significance to meaningless associations

title: The life cycle of a neutron star - David Lunney

multiple-choice.question: What happens to a massive star when it runs out of fuel?

options.label: A
options.text: It expands and becomes a red giant.

options.label: B
options.text: It collapses under its own gravitational pressure and explodes in a supernova.

options.label: C
options.text: It remains stable and continues to shine.

options.label: D
options.text: It disappears from the galaxy.

multiple-choice.question: What is a neutron star?

options.label: A
options.text: A star that is still in its main sequence stage.

options.label: B
options.text: A compact ball of matter so dense that atomic electrons collapse from their quantum orbits into the depths of atomic nuclei.

options.label: C
options.text: A star that has just formed from a nebula.

options.label: D
options.text: A star that is about to explode as a supernova.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of a neutron star's furious rotation slowing over billions of years?

options.label: A
options.text: The star becomes more massive.

options.label: B
options.text: The star's magnetic field becomes weaker.

options.label: C
options.text: The star radiates away its energy in the form of electromagnetic and gravity waves.

options.label: D
options.text: The star disappears from the galaxy.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when two neutron stars collide?

options.label: A
options.text: They merge into a single star.

options.label: B
options.text: They send gravity waves through space-time like ripples from a stone thrown into a calm lake.

options.label: C
options.text: They disappear from the galaxy.

options.label: D
options.text: They become a black hole.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the observation of a neutron star collision in 2017?

options.label: A
options.text: It provided evidence for the origin of heavy elements like gold and platinum.

options.label: B
options.text: It helped pin down the speed of gravity.

options.label: C
options.text: It provided evidence for the existence of dark matter.

options.label: D
options.text: It helped us learn more about the universe's age.
